Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. The Hopkins Microbiology Course (http://hmc.stanford.edu) is an intensive, 4-week course, targeting microbiology students, who seek to obtain an integrated view of microbial life. The course also attracts non-microbiologists, such as physicists or engineers who want to understand microbial biology in order to begin molecular and population level studies. As a "big picture" course, the Hopkins Microbiology Course requires students to have already acquired a significant background in microbiology. While details are important and stressed abundantly as required, the emphasis is on providing the intellectual framework to weave together multiple disciplines into an integrated perspective. This integration is further intensified by providing students with an introduction and hands-on use of biocomputational tools and methods to exploit large biological data sets in order to obtain new biological understandings. Such a broad view is important for students entering not only the academic environment, but also professional fields that involve microbes (chemical, pharmaceutical, or environmental and water industry).

Broader Impacts. This advanced level summer course seeks to provide students with an integrated conceptual framework and experimental tools necessary to understand and study how the interplay of physiology, ecology, evolution, and population genetics causes and maintains diversity of microbes in diverse environments. The course emphasizes a critical, cross-disciplinary integration and application of the knowledge gained and experimental skills learned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With NSF support of six years, we taught a four-week, intensive summer course in Microbiology at the Hopkins Marine Station. This course builds upon the inquiry-driven teaching tradition introduced by C. B. van Niel in his renowned Hopkins Microbiology Course taught in the 1950s and 1960s. The objectives of this course are to enable students:

  1. 1.     to isolate key microorganisms driving the biological and geochemical diversity in marine environments, and to conduct and interpret culture-independent molecular characterization of microbial species;
  2. 2.     to assess, evaluate, and recognize physiological and metabolic diversity;
  3. 3.     to evaluate and experimentally test ecological and evolutionary factors causing microbial diversification, and
  4. 4.     to understand and predict the causes as well as the biological and geochemical consequences of microbial diversity.

 

In these six years, we taught 96 student from more than 12 countries across the world. We had a total of 72 guest speakers and minisymposium participants. The alumni students get together at each ISME and ASM meeting and ‘reminisce’ on the course.

 

The distinguishing aspect of this Hopkins Microbiology Course is the unique integration and application of conceptual ideas and experimentation of microbial physiology, ecology, population genetics and experimental evolution in a cohesive study of the environment.  In traditional University curricula, courses in microbial physiology, genetics, ecology and evolution are taught distinctly from each other often competitively and without much cross-referencing. Each field has its own theories, thinking, and vocabulary, but the synthesis and assimilation of these clearly related aspects of microbial life is often lacking. This Hopkins Microbiology Course is not bound to adhere to such a strict curriculum. Therefore, we assembled an international expert team specializing in physiology, ecology, and evolution to develop a coherent picture of how to understand microbes function in nature and the principles of what constitutes Microbial Diversity, how it is generated, and how it is maintained.

 

Because of the exceptional geographic location, the wealth of scientific information, and the academic environment, the Monterey Bay provides an ideal interdisciplinary learning platform to teach and appreciate the role and dynamics of microbial diversity and ecology. The course involves lectures and scientific and/or service contributions from the Monterey Bay Research Institute (MBARI) at Moss Landing, The Joint Genome Institute (JGI), and scientists from Stanford University and other local research institutions. It is planned, pending on available resources, that this course will be taught on a regular basis every summer.

 

Core teaching staff:

The course was directed by Stanford University Profs. Alfred M. Spormann and Chris A. Francis., Prof. Paul Rainey, Aukland University NZ, and Prof. John Roth, UC Davis. Chris Francis is an expert on microbial biogeochemistry, with an emphasis on the cycling of nitrogen and manganese, as well as microbial ecology. Paul B. Rainey is at the Department of Microbiology at UC Davis, and one of the world’s leading expert in microbial genetics and evolutionary genetics. Alfred Spormann is an expert on microbial physiology, biochemistry, and metabolism. He also served for 4 years (2000-2003) as co-director of a similar course in “Microbial Diversity” at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, MA.

 

In addition to this permanent course faculty, outside local and national scientists and speakers with expertise on topics pertinent to the course objectives extend the expertise of the course. For the ongoing course preparations, demonstrations, and for teaching hands-on techniques to the students, 3 highly qualified course assistants were present. The course includes also scientific field trips to Elkhorn Slough, the Monterey Bay coastline (including Pt. Lobos), the MBARI, the Monterey Bay Aquarium, and other local coastal environments.
